abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Otosclerosis is a bone disorder of the otic capsule and common form of late-onset hearing impairment. Considered a complex disease, little is known about its pathogenesis. Over the past 20 years, ten autosomal dominant loci (<jats:italic>OTSC1-10</jats:italic>) have been mapped but no genes identified. Herein, we map a new <jats:italic>OTSC</jats:italic> locus to a 9.96 Mb region within the FOX gene cluster on 16q24.1 and identify a 15 bp coding deletion in Forkhead Box L1 co-segregating with otosclerosis in a Caucasian family. Pre-operative phenotype ranges from moderate to severe hearing loss to profound sensorineural loss requiring a cochlear implant. Mutant <jats:italic>FOXL1</jats:italic> is both transcribed and translated and correctly locates to the cell nucleus. However, the deletion of 5 residues in the C-terminus of mutant FOXL1 causes a complete loss of transcriptional activity due to loss of secondary (alpha helix) structure. <jats:italic>FOXL1</jats:italic> (rs764026385) was identified in a second unrelated case on a shared background. We conclude that <jats:italic>FOXL1</jats:italic> (rs764026385) is pathogenic and causes autosomal dominant otosclerosis and propose a key inhibitory role for wildtype Foxl1 in bone remodelling in the otic capsule. New insights into the molecular pathology of otosclerosis from this study provide molecular targets for non-invasive therapeutic interventions.</jats:p>
